'''Sir David John Spiegelhalter''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|OBE|FRS}} (born 16 August 1953), is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[statistician]] and [[Winton Professorship of the Public Understanding of Risk|Winton Professor of the Public Understanding of Risk]] in the [[Faculty of Mathematics, University of Cambridge|Statistical Laboratory]] at the [[University of Cambridge]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.statslab.cam.ac.uk/Dept/People/Spiegelhalter/davids.html |title=David Spiegelhalter's Personal Home Page |work= |accessdate=14 September 2011}}</ref> and a Fellow of [[Churchill College, Cambridge]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chu.cam.ac.uk/about/fellows/fellows.php |title=Churchill College: Fellows: List of current Fellows |format= |work= |accessdate=14 September 2011}}</ref><ref name=scopus>{{Scopus| id=35491822900}}</ref><ref name=googlescholar>{{GoogleScholar|id=oz7MFu0AAAAJ}}</ref><ref>{{twitter|d_spiegel}}</ref><ref name=imdb>{{imdb name|4097227}}</ref> Spiegelhalter is an [[ISI highly cited researcher]].

==Education==
Spiegelhalter studied at the [[University of Oxford]] (Bachelor of Arts 1974) and [[University College London]]. He gained his [[Master of Science]] 1975 and Doctor of Philosophy 1978, supervised by [[Adrian Smith (statistician)|Adrian Smith]].<ref name="mathgene"/><ref name="spiegelphd">{{cite thesis |degree=PhD |first=David|last=Spiegelhalter |title=Adaptive inference using finite mixture models |publisher=University College London |date=1978 |url=http://ethos.bl.uk/OrderDetails.do?uin=uk.bl.ethos.473544|authorlink= David Spiegelhalter}}</ref>

==Career==
Spiegelhalter was research assistant in [[Brunel University]] in 1976{{fact|date=June 2014}} and then visiting lecturer at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], 1977–8. After his PhD, he was a research assistant for the [[Royal College of Physicians]]; he was based at the [[University of Nottingham]], where his PhD supervisor, [[Adrian Smith (statistician)|Adrian Smith]], had been appointed a professor.

From 1981 he was at the Medical Research Council Biostatistics Unit at Cambridge. He has been an honorary lecturer at the [[University of Hong Kong]] since 1991.  He has also been a consultant for [[GlaxoSmithKline]], [[Novartis]] and the [[World Anti-Doping Agency]].  He played a leading role in the public inquiries into children's heart surgery at the [[Bristol Royal Infirmary]] and the murders by [[Harold Shipman]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/panorama/4868560.stm | work=BBC News | title=Programme transcript | date=2 April 2006}}</ref> Between 2007 and 2012 he divided his work<ref>{{cite book|title=CAM|publisher=Cambridge University Alumni Association|issue=58|date=October 2009|url=http://www.alumni.cam.ac.uk/sites/www.alumni.cam.ac.uk/files/documents/CAM58.pdf#page=5|page=3|chapter=Don's Diary|first=David|last=Spiegelhalter}}</ref> between the Cambridge [[Statistical Laboratory, University of Cambridge|Statistical Laboratory]] (three-fifths) and the [[Medical Research Council (UK)|Medical Research Council]] [[Biostatistics]] Unit (two-fifths).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mrc-bsu.cam.ac.uk/About%20Us/People.html |title=MRC Biostatistics Unit: People |work= |accessdate=15 September 2011}}</ref> He left the MRC in March 2012<ref>http://www.mrc-bsu.cam.ac.uk/People/formerstaff.html</ref> and now works full-time at the Statistical Laboratory as the [[Winton_Professorship_of_the_Public_Understanding_of_Risk|Winton Professor of the Public Understanding of Risk]].

[[File:David_crop.jpg|thumb|David Spiegelhalter playing with Arco Iris [[Samba band]], July 2009]]

In 2012, Spiegelhalter hosted the [[BBC Four]] documentary ''Tails You Win: The Science of Chance'' which described the application of [[probability]] in everyday life.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p00yh2rc BBC Four – Tails You Win: The Science of Chance]</ref> He also presented a 2013 [[Cambridge Science Festival]] talk, ''How to Spot a Shabby Statistic'' at the Babbage Lecture Theatre in Cambridge.<ref>[http://www.cam.ac.uk/sciencefestival/events/?uid=9e97e687-e818-435a-8ae2-2e10be07d2e8 What’s On » Cambridge Science Festival – How to spot a shabby statistic]</ref><ref name=imdb/>

==Research==
Spiegelhalter's research interests are in statistics<ref name=googlescholar/><ref name="microsoft">{{AcademicSearch|1785081}}</ref><ref name="dblp">{{DBLP|id=Spiegelhalter:David_J=}}</ref> including
* [[Bayesian statistics|Bayesian]] approach to clinical trials, expert systems and complex modelling and epidemiology.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Spiegelhalter | first1 = D. J. | last2 = Best | first2 = N. G. | last3 = Carlin | first3 = B. P. | last4 = Linde | first4 = A. V. D. | title = Bayesian Measures of Model Complexity and Fit | journal = Journal of the Royal Statistical Society | volume = 64 | issue = 4 | doi = 10.1111/1467-9868.00353 | pages = 583–639 | year = 2002 | pmid =  | pmc = }}</ref>
*[[Graphical model]]s of conditional independence. He wrote several papers in the 1980s that showed how probability could be incorporated into expert systems, a problem that seemed intractable at the time. Spiegelhalter showed that while [[frequentist]] probability did not lend itself to expert systems, [[Bayesian probability]] most certainly did.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Lauritzen | first1 = S. L. | last2 = Spiegelhalter | first2 = D. J. | title = Local Computations with Probabilities on Graphical Structures and Their Application to Expert Systems | journal = Journal of the Royal Statistical Society | volume = 50 | issue = 2 | pages = 157–224 | doi =  10.2307/2345762| jstor = 2345762| year = 1988 | pmid =  | pmc = }}</ref>
*[[Statistical software]].<ref>Markov Chain Monte Carlo in Practice, W.R. Gilks, S. Richardson and D.J. Speigelhalter. Chapman & Hall. 1996. ISBN 0-412-05551-1</ref> In the 1990s Spiegelhalter led the [[Medical Research Council (UK)|Medical Research Council]] team that developed [[WinBUGS|WinBUGS ("Bayesian analysis Using Gibbs Sampling")]], a statistical-modeling system allowing [[hierarchical Bayes model|hierarchical]] [[prior distribution]]s. WinBUGS and its successor OpenBUGS specifies [[graphical model]]s using acyclic directed graphs whose nodes are random variables, which are updated using [[Gibbs sampling]] (an updating method for [[Markov chain Monte Carlo]] (MCMC) [[simulation]]).<ref name="WinBUGS" >{{citation|title=WinBUGS User Manual|edition=Version 1.4|date=January 2003|first=David|last=Spiegelhalter|first2=Andrew|last2=Thomas|first3=Nicky|last3=Best|first4=Dave|last4=Lunn|publisher=MRC Biostatistics Unit, Institute of Public Health|location=Robinson Way, Cambridge CB2 2SR, UK|url=http://www.mrc-bsu.cam.ac.uk/bugs|ref=harv|id=[http://www.mrc-bsu.cam.ac.uk/bugs/winbugs/manual14.pdf  PDF document]}}</ref> Earlier Bayesian software had required that the probability distribution for the observed data be an [[exponential family]] and that the prior be its [[conjugate prior|conjugate distribution]]. Allowing flexible choices of prior distributions simplified hierarchical modelling and helped to promote [[multilevel model]]s, which became widely used in epidemiology and education.
*General issues in [[clinical trials]],<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Neuenschwander | first1 = B. | last2 = Capkun-Niggli | first2 = G. | last3 = Branson | first3 = M. | last4 = Spiegelhalter | first4 = D. J. | title = Summarizing historical information on controls in clinical trials | doi = 10.1177/1740774509356002 | journal = Clinical Trials | year = 2010 | pmid =  | pmc = }}</ref> including cluster randomisation, meta-analysis and ethical monitoring.
*Monitoring and comparing clinical and public-health outcomes and their associated publication as performance indicators.
*Public understanding of risk,<ref>{{Cite journal 
| last1 = Spiegelhalter | first1 = D. 
| last2 = Pearson | first2 = M. 
| last3 = Short | first3 = I. 
| doi = 10.1126/science.1191181 
| title = Visualizing Uncertainty About the Future 
| journal = Science 
| volume = 333 
| issue = 6048 
| pages = 1393–1400 
| year = 2011 
| pmid = 21903802 
| pmc = 
}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://understandinguncertainty.org/blogs/david |title=David Spiegelhalter's blog | Understanding Uncertainty |format= |work= |accessdate=15 September 2011}}</ref> including promoting concepts such as the [[micromort]] (a one in a million chance of death) and [[microlife]] (a 30-minute reduction of life expectancy). Media reporting of statistics,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Riesch | first1 = H. | last2 = Spiegelhalter | first2 = D. J. | doi = 10.1080/13698575.2010.540645 | title = 'Careless pork costs lives': Risk stories from science to press release to media | journal = Health, Risk & Society | volume = 13 | pages = 47 | year = 2011 | pmid =  | pmc = }}</ref> risk and probability and the wider conception of uncertainty as going beyond what is measured to model uncertainty, the unknown and the unmeasurable.

==Honours==
*1975 Fellow, [[Royal Statistical Society]]
*1985 Guy Medal in Bronze, Royal Statistical Society
*1990 Award for Outstanding Statistical Application, [[American Statistical Association]]<ref>[http://www.amstat.org/awards/outstandingstatisticalapplicationaward.cfm Outstanding Statistical Application Award], ASA, retrieved 31 March 2014.</ref>
*1993 Chartered Statistician, Royal Statistical Society{{Dubious|CS status only came in about 2002|date=March 2012}}
*1994 Guy Medal in Silver, Royal Statistical Society
*1994 Honorary Doctorate, [[Aalborg University]], Denmark
*[[List of Fellows of the Royal Society elected in 2005|2005 Elected a Fellow of the Royal Society (FRS)]]
*2006 Received an OBE in the [[Queen's Birthday Honours]]
*2006 Appointed Honorary Professor of Biostatistics at [[University of Cambridge]]
*2009 [[Weldon Memorial Prize|Weldon Memorial Prize and Medal]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://isi-web.org/root/weldon-memorial-prize-and-medal |title=Weldon Memorial Prize and Medal – International Statistical Institute |format= |work= |accessdate=15 September 2011}}</ref>
*2010 Honorary Doctorate of Science, [[Plymouth University]]

Spiegelhalter was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the [[2014 Birthday Honours]] for services to statistics.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=60895 |date=14 June 2014 |startpage=b2 |supp=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Gallagher|first1=James|title=Prof Colin Blakemore: Medical research defender knighted|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-27834406|work=BBC News|date=14 June 2014}}</ref>
